_prev_prog_3.Description:
Assuring Safe Operations

H&R has established programs and activities to ensure safe operation of its ammonia, and pentane handling systems.  Some examples include:
+ Production and maintenance personnel are trained in the safe operation and repair of the system.
+ Written operating and maintenance procedures are in place and updated regularly.
+ Full in-depth hazard and operability studies are conducted by qualified personnel at least every 5 years.
+ Complete safety reviews are conducted prior to making any changes to the operation or equipment.
+ Health, environmental, and safety audits are conducted at least every 3 years to ensure compliance with regulations.
+ Maintenance work is planned ahead of time and work permits issued to assure work is performed safely.
+ Regular inspections of equipment, instruments, and piping are conducted to assure integrity of the system.
+ Scheduled preventive maintenance work is performed to assure equipment is safe, reliable, and efficient.
+ All incidents are investigated and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.

Designing for Safety

H&R has installed multiple safeguards and systems to reduce the likelihood of ammonia, and pentane incidents, including:
+ Piping systems where applicable are all welded construction outside of containment areas.
+ The systems are equipped with instrumentation that controls each operation within safe limits.
+ Emergency shutdown systems are installed to immediately isolate each system and minimize upsets.
+ Operating personnel monitor each system regularly to identify any potential problems.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Haarmann & Reimer
                                                               BUSHY PARK SITE
                                                               GOOSE CREEK, SC
                                                               November 10, 2002

I. FACILITY INFORMATION

Haarmann & Reimer (H&R) at Bushy Park, SC,  produces aroma chemicals and cosmetic ingredients.  The H&R corporate headquarters is located In Holtzminden, Germany. ( Haarmann & Reimer GmbH, Muhlenfeldstrasse 1,D-37603, Holzminden, Germany)  The H&R, Bushy Park Site manufactures various forms of menthol, sunscreens, cooling agents, and fragrance specialties.  H&R was formerly a subsidiary of Bayer Corporation who established the Bushy Park site in 1970.  H&R was acquired by EQT Partners on October 1, 2002.  Prior to this date, H&R was included in the RMP considerations of Bayer Corporation who filed their RMP by the statutory deadline.

H&R is located within Bayer's 1650 acre site which is operated as an Industrial Park wherein Bayer owns the land and the various tenants own and operate the assets on the land.  The site is on the Cooper River just a few miles east of Goose Creek, S C.  H&R has contracted with Bayer Corporation to purchase various materials and services.

II. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

H&R is committed to health, the environment and safety.  Haarmann & Reimer considers its responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and the area communities of primary importance in the conduct of its business.  It is H&R's policy to comply with all applicable laws and regulations and to establish and implement responsible practices where laws and regulations do not exist.  Further, H&R will work with government and industry groups to foster the development of appropriate health, environment and safety programs, laws and regulations.  H&R will co

mmunicate with its employees, customers, suppliers, communities and the public to recognize and respond to their concerns and to improve their understanding of the health, environment and safety considerations related to H&R's operations and products.  H&R is committed to continually improving health, environment and safety performance.

Our industry creates products and services that make life better for many people around the world - both today and tomorrow.  We will make continuous progress toward the goal of no accidents, injuries or harm to the environment.  We will adhere to the following principals:

+ To provide chemicals that can be manufactured, transported, used and disposed of safely.
+ To make health, safety, the environment and resource conservation critical considerations for all new and existing products and processes.
+ To provide information on health or environmental risks and pursue protective measures for employees, the public and other key stakeholders.
+ To work with customers, carriers, suppliers, distributors and contractors to foster the safe use, transport and disposal of chemicals.
+ To operate our facilities in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public.
+ To support education and research on the health, safety and environmental effects of our products and processes.
+ To work with others to resolve problems created by past handling and disposal practices.

Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

Haarmann & Reimer has worked with the county and local agencies and response groups to provide information about the chemicals we use on our site.  In addition, the site emergency plans have been integrated with the emergency plans of the county and local fire departments.  H&R has participated in disaster drills held by the LEPC.

Compliance and Commitment to Safety

Protection of our employees and neighbors is our highest priority, and that is why we have installed multiple safeguards to

ensure that all chemicals are handled safely.  We also work closely with our suppliers, other companies, local officials and the public to maintain stringent safety and environmental programs and to minimize risks.  

In keeping with our commitment, H&R has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in compliance with guidelines established by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Under EPA guidelines, facilities that handle certain quantities of regulated chemicals must submit plans that show the consequences of hypothetical chemical releases.  Facilities must also outline their measures to reduce the risk of releases and minimize their effects.

Several processes at the site are regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements listed in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  PSM and RMP complement each other in that PSM is concerned about the employee and RMP is concerned about the public and the environment.  The Bushy Park site is in full compliance with the PSM requirements.  

III. RMP REGULATED SUBSTANCES

A new process is in the final construction stage and is approaching start up. The new process will be in compliance with PSM requirements for the Risk Management Program listed in 40 CFR Part 68.  The new process includes an ammonia refrigeration system and a pentane storage and handling system.  Ammonia is present as liquefied gas under pressure.  It is regulated as a toxic substance.  Pentane is a liquid stored at ambient temperature and is regulated as a flammable material. 

H&R will use anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in the new process area. Prior to now, H&R was included in the Bayer RMP for ammonia.  It is delivered via an overhead pipeline system from Bayer Corporation's plant-wide distribution system.  Ammonia is a colorless gas with a strong pungent odor.  Exposure to ammonia can irritate the eyes, nose and throat.  Exposure to extremely high levels can result in a buildup of fluid in the lungs and can be life threatening.

H&R will

use pentane in the new process area as a solvent in the manufacturing of a fragrance product.  Pentane is a highly flammable liquid that can reach explosive concentrations in the atmosphere if released without restriction.

IV. RELEASE SCENARIOS

Worst case scenarios are included in the plan for ammonia and pentane and an alternative case scenario (or more likely scenario) is included in the plan for each of the two regulated substances.  

H&R receives its liquid ammonia via pipeline from Bayer Corporation.  The worst case scenario for H&R would be Bayer's worst case since most of the liquid ammonia is under Bayer control. The ammonia worst-case scenario is based on the complete failure of the largest process vessel in the Bayer system containing 36,200 pounds of liquid ammonia.  A written operating procedure, high level alarm, and visual level display in the Bayer control room prevent the vessel from being operated with more than 36,200 pounds of liquid ammonia even though the vessel could contain as much as 42,500 pounds.  The maximum distance for the most impacting hypothetical worst case release with no mitigating measures is 2.3 miles to the level of concern (LOC) or toxic end-point.  Several industrial, commercial, residential, public and military facilities are in the potential impact area.

Toxic end-point or Level of Concern (LOC)

The Emergency Response Planning Guideline 2 - Level of Concern (ERPG2-LOC) is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or serious health effects, or symptoms which impair their ability to take protective action.  The release impact distance is the distance down wind to the ERPG2-LOC concentration.  The ERPG2-LOC for ammonia is 0.14 mg/L or 200 parts per million (ppm).  The concentration (estimated from toxicity data) that is immediately dangerous to life and health (IDLH) for ammonia is 300 ppm.

Haa

rmann & Reimer will use pentane as a solvent in the new fragrance chemical manufacturing process.  Pentane will be stored in a 70 m3 tank with a maximum working capacity of 60 m3 or 79,200 pounds of liquid.  The storage tank is located in a diked area (passive mitigation).  The worst case scenario would be the complete failure of the storage tank and all contents spill into the dike.  The dike is considered in the mitigation since it is a passive measure.  In this worst-case scenario, the entire quantity released was assumed to have formed a vapor cloud, which then detonated. The 1 pound per square inch overpressure endpoint (defined in the EPA requirements) for this scenario is the threshold for potentially serious injuries to people from flying glass, falling debris, and other explosion effects.  The distance to the overpressure endpoint for this case would be 0.1 miles.  This distance would effect Bayer Corporation areas around the H&R site but would not impact areas beyond the fence line for the total Bayer Industrial Park.

All scenarios evaluated used EPA's published model, RMPComp, to provide toxic end-point determinations and flammablity impact based on EPA published levels of concern (LOC).  Other models did not provide satisfactory estimates for use in evaluating the maximum end-point distance.  Public and environmental protection requires conservative results.  Both substances were evaluated for the alternate scenario and the information is included in the plan.  

More-Likely Scenarios

Anhydrous ammonia and pentane process systems are similar in function.  Each has a storage container or containers and a transfer system which includes transfer pump(s) and piping to deliver the material to an end use function.  The more likely scenario for each could  involve a breach in the integrity of the piping system.  A flange leak or rupture could constitute a likely potential for a release of the regulated substance.  The ammonia piping system is constructed with

welded pipe where a leak could not occur.  Flanged connections are used for pumps, vessel attachment  and critical control valves so they can be taken out easily when repair or replacement is necessary.  

The pentane piping system is similar, but with a combination of flanged and welded pipe up to the diked storage vessels and transfer pump.  The opportunity for leaks and/or ruptures is greater.  Since the pentane system will be new to operations, no accident history for handling pentane is available for comparison.  Similar systems in operation were considered.

The alternative scenario is a hypothetical release that is more realistic than the worst-case scenario.  In this scenario, safety and emergency systems operate as expected, and plant personnel respond to take action to control and stop the release.

Ammonia scenario assumptions:

+ Partial failure of the piping system containing ammonia liquid under pressure. 
+ Detection of ammonia by instruments or personnel in the area, shutdown of the ammonia supply equipment by remote control, and closure of valves by site personnel to stop the leak.
+ Release during typical weather conditions experienced at the site.

The alternative release scenario for ammonia is based on a 1.0 inch diameter hole (broken pipe nozzle) in the pressure vessel at a flanged connection (gas side) containing liquid and gaseous ammonia that would release 192 pounds of ammonia gas per minute.  The time to discovery and system shut down is based on a 20-minute release.  The distance to the toxic end-point is estimated to be 0.1 miles using EPA's RMP*Comp model.  No mitigating factors were included.  The impact area is slightly off H&R's site but within the Bayer Industrial Park fence line.

Pentane scenario assumptions:

+ Hose connection at tank truck comes off during unloading operation of pentane liquid at ambient temperature.
+ Detection of the lost connection by operator who performs unloading operation and shutoff of the pentane flow

from the tank truck by the operator in attendance.
+ Release during typical weather conditions experienced at the site.

The alternative release scenario for pentane is based on the unloading hose coming off the connection to the tank truck during unloading operations.  The amount lost (898 pounds) would be the contents of the hose and the amount of pentane that would flow out of the tank truck before the attending operator could shut off  the emergency valve.   The time to discovery and system shut down is based on a 1-minute release.  The distance to the lower flammability limit for this regulated substance under the RMP Rule is estimated to be 0.1 miles using EPA's RMP*Comp model.  The impact area is within the Bayer Industrial Park fence-line.

V. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the past five years H&R has not experienced any release of ammonia or pentane that requires listing in the RMP information we are submitting.  

VI. EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Incident and Emergency Guidelines

H&R has multiple safeguards in place to ensure safe handling of ammonia and pentane and to prevent releases of these substances.  Our facility is prepared to handle emergencies such as hurricanes and tornadoes as well as chemical releases.  In the unlikely event a release occurs, we work to contain the release quickly and to minimize its impact on plant personnel and neighbors.  If a release occurs equipment that supplies the regulated substance would be shut down quickly by remote control.

H&R is a partner in the Bayer Industrial Park.  Bayer manages the Industrial Park Emergency Operations Center (EOC) that H&R participates in.  If a release occurs, the EOC is activated and the follow actions are implemented:
+ The plant alarm would be sounded and the emergency communicated to plant personnel over the emergency alert system.
+ Trained on-site emergency response teams would be activated and take prompt action to control and stop the release. 
+ Emergency response personnel would eva

luate the extent and impact of the release
+ If the release would have potential off-site impact, or outside assistance needed, local and county emergency response personnel would be notified and activated.
+ Neighbors in the immediate area that might be affected would be notified and advised to take appropriate action.
+ If necessary, Site specialists would be activated to perform computer modeling to estimate the area affected by the release. 
+ If needed, the site has immediate access to emergency resources and assistance from its corporate headquarters.

Training and Preparation

H&R trains employees on the safe handling of ammonia and pentane and how to respond appropriately, should a release occur.  Some examples of our preparation and training include:
+ Written procedures to handle all types of emergencies.
+ Regularly scheduled safety training for operators and maintenance personnel responsible for the regulated substance system.

 H&R is a partner in the Bayer Industrial Park.  Bayer manages various overall Industrial Park Emergency Services that H&R participates in.  These services include the following:
+ Trained and experienced on-site emergency response teams ( Fire & Rescue, EMT's, and Hazmat ).
+ Emergency planning with the local fire department and county emergency preparedness personnel.
+ Planning and training with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and participation in annual drills.
+ Routine testing of plant emergency response, alerting, and communications systems.
+ Fully equipped emergency response vehicles (fire truck, ambulance, and hazmat truck).
+ Emergency response personnel trained annually at nationally recognized schools.
+ Certified Hazmat Team to respond to off-site transportation and distribution incidents.

VIII. IMPROVING SAFETY PERFORMANCE

H&R has an ongoing commitment to safety.  As proof of this, from January 1996 to the present, there has only been one OSHA recordable injury at H&R?s Busy Park Plant.  H&R uses a structured approach to safety management that relies strongly on the participation of all employees and insures communication of safety related information at all levels of the plant.  In addition H&R?s Continuous Improvement Program and ISO-9000 process include safety performance and improvement on an equal basis with quality and productivity.

H&R management encourages all of the Continuous Improvement teams to review and evaluate operations and recommend safety, environmental, and operational improvements.  This philosophy applies to our entire facility and continues to expand its scope to include operations in the new plant.  Past efforts in other areas of the plant have resulted in projects like:
1. Redesign of an organic/water separator tank that improved product and raw material recovery from the wastewater stream    and lowered BOD loading in wastewater influent to the treatment plant.
2. Redesign of the battery changing and charging building for safer handling of large electric fork truck batteries.  The    redesign included improved spill prevention and containment features to better prevent spills of the battery acid.
3. A three-phase review and upgrade of the ladders, platforms and handrails associated with our chemical storage tanks to    improve safety conditions and provide a safer work environment for our employees.
4. The relocation and installation of our truck unloading station with improved safety features, including guarded    platforms and mechanical gangways, providing safe access to the top of the truck for the purpose of sample extraction.     In addition, the new truck unloading facility is designed with improved spill containment and material recovery       features.
